nodes.text: Differences in individual teacher quality cause meaningful differences in elementary students' standardized reading and math achievement and can be identified using panel data with teacher and student fixed effects
Estimate teacher fixed effects in linear test score regressions while controlling for student fixed characteristics, classroom covariates, school-year effects, and teacher experience

Use panel of elementary student nationally standardized test scores and teacher assignments from two contiguous New Jersey districts, 1989-1990 to 2000-2001, with student demographics and teacher characteristics

Identification assumptions: (a) include student fixed effects; (b) grade-standardized scores allow omitting grade effects; (c) marginal experience effects are zero after a cutoff (ten years) to separate year and experience
Teacher fixed effects are jointly highly significant predictors of student test scores across reading vocabulary, reading comprehension, math computation and math concepts

Magnitude: a one standard deviation increase in teacher quality raises reading by about 0.20 standard deviations and math by about 0.24 standard deviations on national standardized scales (estimates from NCE scores)

Teaching experience has statistically significant positive effects on reading scores: roughly 4 NCE points (about 0.2 SD) for ten years of experience in reading vocabulary and comprehension, with gains concentrated early- to mid-career
Little or no estimated gains from experience for math subjects; math computation shows small early gains but no sustained positive trend, math concepts show no significant experience effect

Classroom-specific observable controls (class size, classmates' past average test score, split-level classroom indicators) are not significant predictors of test scores in these districts once teacher and student fixed effects are included

Omitting teacher fixed effects biases estimated experience effects; naive cross-teacher variation estimates understate or misstate experience returns because teacher fixed quality correlates with experience

Observed correlation between estimated teacher fixed effects and experience varies by subject (negative in vocabulary, small elsewhere), illustrating potential direction of bias when fixed effects are omitted
Findings are based on two similar New Jersey elementary districts and may underestimate broader cross-district variation; generalizability to statewide or national teacher distributions is limited

Variance decomposition: teacher fixed effects and experience account for a nontrivial share of policy-relevant test score variance; estimates imply teachers explain lower-bound ~4-9% and upper-bound ~16-23% of policy-relevant variance depending on assumptions

Teacher quality correlates positively across subjects: pairwise correlations of teacher fixed effects are positive (higher among the three non-vocabulary tests), suggesting teachers who are effective in one subject tend to be effective in others

Policy implication: policies aiming to improve student achievement should focus on identifying and rewarding teacher performance (value-added measures or evaluations) rather than relying solely on observable credentials like degrees or experience beyond early years
